sub_title: Prof. of Urban Development & Department Head Management in the Built Environment
summary:
Governance of sustainable urban areas is at the core of Ellen's research and teaching. With a background in urban planning and public policy, she analyzes and advises on decision-making in complex, multi-actor settings, public and private, including questions of governance, organisation, and regulation. As professor of Urban Development Management she aims to further develop a generalized, theoretical understanding of processes of urban development and the management thereof, which can be of use to stakeholders involved in urban development projects.
Ellen has published on topics as institutional barriers for sustainable construction, the mainstreaming of green building, sustainable urban development, renewable energy policy and implementation, and evaluation of environmental policy. She has edited 'Sustainable Urban Environments: an Ecosystem Approach' (Springer, 2012). The book "Constructing Green, the Social Structures of Sustainabilty" (eds. A. Hoffman & R. Henn) featuring a chapter by Ellen van Bueren and Bertien Broekhans on Mainstreaming Niche Innovations received Honorable Mention for the 2014 Best Book Award from the Organizations & Natural Environment Division of the Academy of Management.

The understanding of these processes of change and how to manage them is at the core of the chair of Urban Development Management. The change processes are highly contextual: each area has its own unique constellation of physical, technological and social characteristics. At the same time there are regional, national, global, and sometimes contradictory, developments that influence urban developments. Within these wider trends and influences, Urban Development Management calls for contingent, area-based approaches, identifying and making use of opportunities for urban improvements in a particular area, which can range from a neighbourhood or district level to a city or regional level.
The object of study is highly empirical, calling for close interaction with the stakeholders involved in a particular area to understand the direction of change, the drivers of and barriers to change in that area and the effects and outcomes of the management approaches used. Based on such empirical work, the chair aims to (further) develop a more generalized and theoretical understanding of Urban Development Management, which can be of use to stakeholders involved in urban development projects and processes.', 'title': 'Professor of Urban Development Management', 'employment_type': None}, {'location': 'The Hague Area, Netherlands', 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}, 'end': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2021}}, 'company': 'Delft University of Technology', 'description': 'At the section Policy, Organisation, Law and Gaming we study processes of governance and decision-making at the interface of technology and society.
